choices.text: Reflected light is used as a light source

questions.text: A patient admitted with acute renal failure. Urine microscopy image shown here revealed the cause. All the following are true regarding this microscope except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Image obtained from Dark field Microscope.
  • Used to demonstrate spirochetes
  • Used to demonstrate Motility
  • Reflected light is used as a light source

questions.text: Choose the correct function of the structure marked in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • The structure marked here is convoluted membranous body formed as invaginations of the plasma membrane into the cytoplasm -  Septal mesosome.
  • It facilitates the septum formation at the time of binary fission and Compartmenting of DNA
  • Lateral mesosome – Respiration.

questions.text: Bacteriocin production occurs in which phase of the bacterial growth curve shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bacteriocin production, Sporulation, Storage granules formation seen in Stationary phase.

Morphology, biochemical properties, antibiogram – Log phase

Involutional form – Decline phase.

questions.text: An urine specimen was collected and kept in the room temperature. The initial amount of bacteria in the specimen was 2000/ml. The pathogen had a generation time of 40 minutes and lag period of 60 minutes. After 3 hours, how many bacteria present in the specimen.8,000/ml
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Initial count – 2,000

Lag period – 60 min – no multiplication

Log period – 40 minutes 

Total 3 hours (180 min)

Active log period  =180 -60 = 120 min (3 logs (40X3)

Final count = 2000X 23 = 16,000

questions.text: A Gram-negative pathogen isolated from wound infection is positive for a biochemical test as shown in the image. Choose the pathogen based on this clue.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Image shown here is Indole test – Positive reaction. A red ring on the top.

Among the given choices, Indole positive and Gram negative rod is Proteus vulgaris. 

Enterococcus is gram positive cocci.

questions.text: A culture of bacteria is incubated with bacteriophages and then centrifuged to separate the bacterial cells from the supernatant. The supernatant above the cells is then transferred to a new culture of bacteria When the bacteriophage infected culture is plated on solid medium, 5 clones of bacteria are seen to acquire 5 new and distinct genetic traits. Which of the following best describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Transduction is the delivery of bacterial genes, from one bacterium to another   virus vector (bacteriophage). 
  • The phage picks up the bacterial DNA through an error in phage production. 
  • There are two types of transduction: generalized (error of lytic virus life cycle) and specialized (error of temperate virus life cycle). 
  • Since the question describes the clones of bacteria acquiring 5 new and distinct traits, generalized transduction has occurred. 
  • The phenomenon is in essence a "packaging error " in which portions of bacterial DNA are accidentally included in progeny phage,rendering the phages defective, and thus incapable of producing a productive infection, but able to pass on genes to another bacterium. 
  • Since the bacterial DNA that is accidentally packaged by the phages may be any piece of the chromosome, thepotential traits transferred cannot be predicted.

questions.text: Image shown here is an example for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Concurrent disinfection – Application of disinfective measures as soon as possible after the discharge of infectious material from the body of an infectious person. Consists of disinfection of urine ,faeces , vomit, clothes ,hands ,dressings, apron ,gloves
  • Terminal disinfection - Application of disinfective measures after the patient has died or has ceased to be a source of infection.
  • Precurrent (prophylactic) disinfection – Disinfection of water by chlorine, pasteurization of milk ,hand washing.

questions.text: Equipment shown in the image is used to sterilize disposable plastic syringes and the method is named as cold sterilization. Name the quality control agent used for this equipment.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cold sterilization is Gamma radiation.

Ionizing radiation used for Disposable plastics, Catgut..etc.

Quality control agent is Bacillus pumilus.

questions.text: Choose the correct application of the item shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Image shown here is membrane filter. Pore size usually 0.22 micrometer.
  • Main application is bacteriological analysis of water.
  • Air purification – HEPA filter
  • Vaccines – Seitz filter

questions.text: The equipment shown here is used to cultivate all the following organisms except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Image shown here is Gaspak

Main application is cultivation of anaerobic organisms

Bordetella is obligate aerobe. All other choices are anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: Image shown here is an example for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Immunoglobulins – Passive artificial immunity

Vaccines – Active artificial immunity

Maternal antibodies – Passive natural immunity

Infections – Active natural immunity

questions.text: A 5-year-old suddenly complains of sore throat, malaise, and low-grade fever. Examination reveals a white, thick coating of the tonsils, uvula, and palate. Attempts to scrape the coating cause bleeding. Organism grows in Potassium tellurite agar and confirms the diagnosis. To demonstrate the toxigenicity of the pathogen, laboratory performed a test which is shown in the image. Choose the correct name of the procedure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Single diffusion in one dimension - Oudin procedure
  • Single diffusion in Two dimension - Mancini procedure
  • Double diffusion in one dimension - Oakley–Fulthrope procedure
  • Double diffusion in two dimension - Ouchterlony procedure

questions.text: A male infant developed tonic convulsions a few days after birth and was found to be hypocalcemic. Of note, he was born with a cleft palate, widely spaced eyes, and ears residing lower than normal. Cardiac defects also became apparent in the neonatal period. A lateral view chest radiograph revealed a diminished thymic shadow. What genetic defect could account for the problems seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • This child has congenital thymic aplasia or DiGeorge syndrome, which is associated with a deletion in chromosome 22q11.2. 
  • Other syndromes associated with this deletion include velocardiofacial syndrome and conotruncal anomaly face syndrome. 
  • All these syndromes share characteristic facial features, cardiac abnormalities and recurrent infections. These syndromes represent a developmental defect involving the pharyngeal arches and pouches.

questions.text: The complement system plays a key role in the host defense process. Which of the following components of this system is the most important in chemotaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • C3a and C5a are potent mediators of inflammation; that is, they have anaphylatoxin activity. 
  • This activity is characterized by smooth-muscle contraction and the degranulation of mast cells and basophils leading to the release of histamine and other vasoactive substances, causing increased vascular (capillary) permeability. 
  • C5a is the most potent of these anaphylatoxins; however, it also serves another role as a potent chemotactic agent, attracting olymorphonucleated neutrophils and macrophages to the site of inflammation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student develops a rash. She works part-time in a pediatric AIDS clinic. Her blood is drawn and tested for specific antibody to the chicken pox virus (varicella-zoster). Which of the following antibody classes would you expect to find if she is immune to chicken pox?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • The initial response to a new infection is with an IgM class antibody. 
  • IgM develops quickly and usually disappears within a few months. 
  • The secondary response is IgG and reflects the patient’s immune status or, in the case of chicken pox, a vaccination given.

choices.text: IL-10 and transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β)

questions.text: Persons with helminth infections mount immunologic responses that involve IgE and eosinophils. Which two cytokines are most important for these responses to occur
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • IL-4 and IL-5. IL-1 and TNF (choice A) are cytokines produced by activated phagocytes and T cells promoting inflammation. 
  • IL-10 and TGF-β  are cytokines produced by Th2, macrophages, and regulatory T cells to suppress the immune response as a mechanism of regulating immunity.
  • IL-12 and IFN-γ  are cytokines which promote Th1 differentiation and activation of macrophages (enhance phagocytosis).

questions.text: In a laboratory, while performing antibody detection from a patient, the antibody titre shown in Zone 1 leads to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Ag -AB assay
  • Reaction occurs in zone of equalance
  • Zone 1 is antibody excess – Prozone phenomenon.
  • If patient serum has excess antibody the reaction become negative and it leads to false negative.

questions.text: Idiotypic variation of immunoglobulin is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Idiotypes are the antigenic determinants formed by the specific amino acids in the hypervariable region.
  • Each idiotype is unique for the immunoglobulin produced by a specific clone of antibody-producing cells. 
  • Anti-idiotype antibody reacts only with the hypervariable region of the specific immunoglobulin molecule that induced it.

questions.text: Interpret the test shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Ouchterlony test
  • Antigen 1 and antigen 2 are Partially identical.

questions.text: A Gram positive cocci isolated from surgical site wound infection exhibits coagulase test positive. Culture on blood agar shown in the image. All the following are the virulent factors of this pathogen except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Gram positive cocci Catalase Positive, Coagulase positive, Most common cause of Surgical site infections is Staphylococcus aureus.
  • All the options are virulent factors except M protein.
  • M protein seen in GAS.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of multiple yellowish lesions on his face and neck. He is up to date on his immunizations. Physical examination shows many lesions, up to 4 cm in diameter, with yellow crusting on the surface. There are also other sites with small blisters and with areas oozing small amounts of clear fluid. Gram stain of the fluid shown in the image. Which of the following is the most common sequelae of this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • It’s a case of Impetigo. Grams smear showns Gram Positive cocci in chains suggestive of S. pyogenes.
  • The nonsuppurative sequelae of skin lesions is Post Streptococcal Glomerular Nephritis (PSGN).
  • Cola colour urine and puffy face are the classical clinical features.
  • Sore throat leads to Acute Rheumatic fever.

questions.text: Choose the correct biotype of Corynebacterium diphtheriae which produces Daisy head colonies
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • C. diphtheriae biotype gravis – Daisy head colonies
  • C. diphtheriae biotype intermedius – Frog egg colonies
  • C. diphtheriae biotype mitis – Poached egg colonies

choices.text: Acts on EF2 and inhibits protein synthesis

questions.text: A bacterial pathogen was isolated from a cutaneous lesion as shown in the image. Gram smear shows typical Box car appearance of Gram-Positive bacilli. The pathogen responsible for this patient’s condition produces a toxin with which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Image shown here is Eschar – Cutaneous anthrax caused by B. anthracis.
  • Anthrax toxin has 3 components.
  • Edema factor is a component of the anthrax toxin. 
  • It is a calmodulin-dependent adenylate cyclase, which acts by converting adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). 
  • This causes an increase in the cellular cAMP levels, leading to cellular edema within the target tissues. 
  • The edema factor also causes inhibition of neutrophil function and lowers the production of tumor necrosis factor (TNF-alpha) and interleukin-6 (IL-6) by monocytes

questions.text: A 7-day-old infant presents to the Pediatric OPD with a fever, poor feeding, and a bulging fontanelle. During her physical examination, she begins to convulse. CSF microscopy revealed motile bacilli which exhibits a typical growth pattern in semisolid agar as shown in the image. Choose the correct motility pattern of this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • It is a case of neonatal meningitis.
  • The organism produces a typical umbrella turbidity in semisolid nutrient agar as shown in the picture suggestive of Listeria monocytogenes.
  • L. monocytogenes in adults may cause meningitis, meningoencephalitis, septicemia, endocarditis, and brain abscess. 
  • It exhibits tumbling motility.
  • Darting motility – Vibrio
  • Lashing motility – Listeria
  • Gliding motility - Mycoplasma

questions.text: A swab obtained from gun shot wound exhibits growth in Robertson cooked meat medium. This pathogen is gram-positive, spore-forming bacilli. The pathogen exhibits a typical appearance in egg based medium as shown in the image. Choose the correct name of this reaction.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • This pathogen is an anaerobe.
  • Opalescent colonies in egg based medium -  Naegler’s  reaction 
  • Demonstration of  alpha toxin of C. perfringens
  • Alpha-toxin is the most important toxin produced by all strains of C. perfringens. The largest volumes of alpha-toxin are provided by C. perfringens type A strain. 
  • The alpha-toxin is a lecithinase, a phospholipase C, which in the presence of calcium and magnesium ions breaks down lecithin into phosphoryl choline and diglyceride.
  • The toxin is responsible for toxaemia typically observed during gas gangrene. 
  • It is lethal, dermonecrotic, and hemolytic.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female is brought to the causality  with high fever and confusion. She complains of chills and myalgias, and physical examination reveals a rash with petechial hemorrhage. skin biopsy reveals the gram-negative diplococci which ferments maltose. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • The patient has symptoms of meningococcemia, a form of sepsis due to intravascular multiplication of Neisseria meningitidis. 
  • It is a Gram negative bacteria lens shaped diplococci. Ferements maltose.
  • Meningococcemia may progress to fulminant meningococcemia with bilateral hemorrhage into and destruction of the adrenal glands, a condition known as Waterhouse-Friederichsen syndrome. 
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) & endocervicitis are typical complications of Neisseria gonorrhoeae. 
  • Several organisms may cause osteomyelitis, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. 
  • Osteomyelitis is not a common complication of meningococcemia.

choices.text: It is resistant to complement-mediated lysis
Its pili undergo antigenic and phase variation

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of progressive joint pain in her ankles, knees, and wrists She has had three similar episodes within the past several years. She is sexually active has multiple partners, and occasionally uses protection. Physical examination shows a diffuse petechial rash over the trunk and extensor surfaces. The ankles and knees are swollen, red. and tender with decreased range of motion, and there is tenderness over the tendon sheaths of the hands and forearms. Blood cultures are positive by using New York city medium.. Examination of joint fluid shows a white cell count of 22,000/mms. Which of the following is a characteristic of the most likely causal organism that allows it to cause recurrent infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • This is a classic presentation of Neisseria gonorrhea (septic} arthritis, where there is a direct bacterial invasion of the joint space.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative, oxidase positive diplococcus that is transmitted sexually, ft can be cultured on chocolate agar and the chocolate agar variant Thayer-Martin agar, which contain an assortment of antibiotics that select for Neisseria species.
  • There are 2 entities of gonococcal arthritis :* Localized septic gonococcal monoarticular arthritis (40% of patients).* Disseminated gonococcal dermatitis-arthritis syndrome (60% of patients), as seen in this vignette. 
  • Gonococcal dermatitis-arthritis syndrome has a triad of dermatitis, tenosynovitis, and polyarthritis, as seen in our patient.
  • Patients with gonococcal septic arthritis commonly present with/ever. These symptoms may develop over a few days to a few weeks. 
  • Patients are continuously susceptible to reinfection because of antigenic variation and phase variation of the pili. These pili are also protective against phagocytosis and mediate attachment to the mucosal surfaces. 
  • Even in patients with negative blood cultures, the high numbers of leukocytes in the joint fluid and the signs of endotoxin rash should suggest the diagnosis of gonococcal arthritis in a sexually active age group.

questions.text: Choose the pigment producing rapid growing  atypical mycobacteria
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Rapid growers – Pigment producers – M. smegmatis & M. phlei
  • Rapid growers – Non Pigment producers – M. fortuitum, M. chelonei
  • M. asiaticum – Photochromogen
  • M. celatum – Scotochromogen
  • M. paratuberculosis – Non chromogen.

questions.text: A stool sample was taken from a 20-year-old male who presented with profuse watery diarrhea. A microbiologist identified the causative agent was V. cholerae biotype El Tor. Choose the correct enrichment medium for this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Alkaline peptone water is the enrichment medium for V. cholerae.
  • Selenite F broth – Shigella & Salmonella
  • Tetrathionate both – Anaerobic bacteria
  • Brain Heart infusion agar – Enriched medium.

questions.text: Many urine samples for culture and sensitivity received from Nephrology ward, shows non lactose fermenting colonies in MacConkey agar and also Positive for PPA test. Name the epidemiological method shown in the image, used to identify the strain variation. Choose the correct method
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • It is used to determine the identity or nonidentity of strains of Proteus. 
  • This is based on the observations that when two identical strains of Proteus are inoculated at two different sites on a solid agar that does not inhibit swarming, then those two strains show swarming, which coalesce together without any demarcation. 
  • However, if the strains are not identical, then the swarming strains do not coalesce together, instead are separated from each other with a clearly visible furrow between swarming of the two. 
  • This is known as Dienes phenomenon.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever, shaking chills and a productive cough. She has a history of alcohol abuse. Culture of the sputum grows gram-negative lactose-fermenting rods with a typical colony morphology as shown in the image. Chest X ray shows lobar cavitation. Choose the correct pathogen .
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Alcohol abuse, Lobar pneumonia, Gram negative lactose fermenting microbe with mucoid colonies suggestive of Kleb. pneumoniae.
  • E. Klebsiella pneumoniae is a well recognized cause of community-acquired lobar pneumonia associated with cavitation. 
  • It is a gram-negative, oxidase negative rod with a large polysaccharide capsule. It produces mucoid, lactosefermenting colonies on MacConkey agar. 
  • It is found typically in alcoholics over 40 years of age with underlying diabetes or obstructive lung disease. Klebsiella pneumoniae mimics Streptococcus pneumoniae as a pulmonary pathogen, except that Klebsiella has a greater tendency to progress to lung abscess and empyema. 
  • Third-generation cephalosporins with or without an aminoglycoside can be used for the treatment of a Klebsiella pneumoniae infection. 
  • Fluoroquinolones may also be used

choices.text: Depolymerization of actin filaments in gastrointestinal mucosal cells, leading to mucosal cell death
Increased intracellular cAMP in gastrointestinal mucosal cells, resulting in decreased absorption and increased secretion in the digestive tract
Inhibition of elongation factor-2 (EF-2), resulting in decreased protein synthesis in gastrointestinal mucosal cells
Inhibition of elongation factor-2 (EF-2), resulting in decreased protein synthesis in gastrointestinal mucosal cells

questions.text: A 27-year-old male suddenly develops severe abdominal cramping and bloody diarrhea. The patient reports consuming undercooked ground beef four days prior to the onset of the symptoms. Pathogen shows colorless colonies in Macconkey sorbitol agar. Which of the following best describes the toxin-mediated mechanism of this disease process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • This patient’s presentation is consistent with an Enterohemorrhagic E. coli infection (EHEC), which leads to colitis through inhibition of the 60S/28S ribosomal subunit and decreased protein synthesis in gastrointestinal mucosal cells. 
  • It won’t ferment sorbitol.
  • EHEC produces a shiga-like toxin. Shiga-like toxin prevents tRNA binding to the 60S/ 28S ribosomal subunit, thereby inhibiting protein synthesis and leading to subsequent death of gastrointestinal mucosal cells. Shiga-like toxin not only yields bloody diarrhea through damage to intestinal mucosal cells but can also result in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) through damage to renal endothelial cells. O157:H7 is the most common EHEC strain.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man abruptly develops high grade fever,  shakes, a severe headache, and muscle pain. He working as a gardener and supervises water sprinklers. He initially had a dry, insignificant cough but over the next few days he developed marked shortness of breath that necessitated assisted ventilation. Culture of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid on buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) show growth of a predominant organism. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • This patient has a severe, potentially fatal atypical pneumonia with prominent systemic symptoms.
  • Culture on buffererd charcoal lyeast extract {BCYE}agar  is the specific due that the organism is Legionella pneumophila.
  •  The disease is respiratory legionellosis, also known as Legionnaires' disease because the disease was first described when it occurred inepidemic form following an American Legion convention at a Philadelphia hotel. 
  • Exposure to this bacteria is usually associated with aerosol-producing devices such as air-conditioners, mist machines, sprinklers etc. 
  • Patients tend to be older (age 40-70 years) and may have   including cigarette use, alcoholism, diabetes, chronic illness, or immunosuppressive therapy.
  • Additional manifestations of patients with legionellosis includes hyponatremia 
  • DOC : Azithromycin

questions.text: A 40 year old farmer who is a veterinarian on a cattle ranch comes to the physician because of malaise, drenching sweats, unexplained weight loss and weakness for the past 2 months. He also has had an intermittent fever ranging up to 39 4°C. Pathogen isolated from Bone marrow aspirate culture is commonly called as Bang’s bacillus. Choose the correct selective medium for the pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • It’s a case of Brucellosis. B. abortus is otherwise called as Bang’s bacillus.
  • Reservoir is cattle.
  • Brucella abortus produces a granulomatous disease with caseating granulomas that is chronic in nature. 
  • Most cases are associated with cattle or originate from exposure to unpasteurized milk and cheese, in which it produces spontaneous abortions. Most cases of brucellosis produce mild disease or fevers of unknown origin. 
  • However, Brucella species can infect the cardiovascular system and cause endocarditis. The aortic valve is most commonly involved, followed by the mitral valve and then both.
  • Most cases of brucellosis are associated with occupational exposure in persons such as veterinarians, ranchers, and those who handle animal carcasses 
  • Doxycycline with rifampin or streptomycin is the recommended treatment of choice for this condition

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe respiratory distress. His sister says that he had previously been healthy, but yesterday he began to develop sudden chills a high fever, malaise nausea and vomiting and headache. He now has chest pain, difficulty breathing cough and blood-tinged sputum. Sputum microscopy shown in the image. In Ghee broth it exhibits stalactite pattern growth. Choose the correct pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Safety pin appearance and stalactite growth in ghee boroth suggestive of Plague.
  • Plague has not been eradicated and is still encountered in sporadic cases in various places in the world, including Asia, Africa, parts of Europe, and the U.S. Southwest. 
  • The causative organism is Yersinia pestis, which is endemic in many wild-rodent populations and can be transmitted to humans either by direct contact or by flea bite.
  • Human plague may take many forms, including pestis minor (mild lymphadenopathy], bubonic plague (prominent hemorrhagic lymphadenopathy l pneumonic plague, and septicemic plague.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child of is brought to the pediatric clinic with one week paroxysmal cough with inspiratory whoops, frequently associated with vomiting. The parents profess religious objections to childhood vaccinations, but permit withdrawal of a blood sample, which reveals a lymphocytosis of 44,000/mm3.  Production of lymphocytosis, insulin secretion, and histamine sensitization are all results of which attribute of this organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • The disease here is whooping cough, caused by Bordetella pertussis. The pertussis toxin (also known as the lymphocytosis-promoting toxin) is not believed to be directly cytotoxic, but stimulates adenylate cyclase by ribosylating regulatory proteins. 
  • It causes a variety of effects depending on the cell type involved: insulin secretion, lymphocytosis, and alteration of immune effector cells. 
  • The filamentous hemagglutinin mediates attachment; the adenylate cyclase toxin  stimulates local edema; the organism produces only a small zone of hemolysis around its colonies.
  • It is an aerobe and does not grow anaerobically. All systemic manifestations of the disease arise from the circulation of the toxins, not the organism itself .

questions.text: After a week in the intensive care unit following an automobile accident, an 18-year-old college student develops increased urinary urgency, burning micturition and lower abdominal pain. His urine culture plate shown in the image which revealed the probable pathogen. What is the most likely organism causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Serratia is a gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic bacillus.
  • Serratia is a common cause of nosocomial urinary tract infections, along with E. coli, Proteus, Klebsiella and Pseudomonas. 
  • Some strains produce a red pigment.
  • Nosocomial infections generally are more resistant than community acquired infections.

choices.text: Charcoal yeast extract with iron and cysteine
Chocolate agar with factors V and X

questions.text: A young girl from a rural area is presented with complaints of fever, cough, and fatigue for the past 2 weeks. The physician notices that the patient is having intermittent bouts of many coughs in a single breath, followed by a deep inspiration. The parents report that this pattern of coughing had started in the past 2 days. The physician informs them that their daughter will most likely recover with only supportive care. However, for confirmation of diagnosis, a swab is obtained from the posterior nasopharynx is sent for culture for a specific organism. Which of the following culture media will be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • This patient is presenting with a classic case of whooping cough caused by Bordetella pertussis. 
  • The initial phase is characterized by flu-like symptoms for the first 1- 2 weeks. 
  • During this time, erythromycin is an effective treatment . 
  • The second phase, the paroxysmal stage, is marked by bouts of multiple coughs in a single breath followed by a deep inspiration (the classic whooping cough) . Treatment during this phase does not change the disease course, so only supportive care is indicated, and the infection ought to pass in otherwise healthy individuals. 
  • Infants who are not vaccinated are at risk for infect ion. B. pertussis can only be cultured on Bordet-Gengou medium and Regan Lowe medium.

questions.text: Selective medium for the bacteria causing Andaman fever is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Andaman fever is a common name for Leptospirosis.
  • Selective media for leptospira are EMJH medium, Korthof medium and Fletcher medium

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy with sickle cell disease presented with complaints of severe pain in the area of his right humerus. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. A radiograph is obtained that shows lytic changes and periosteal elevation in the middle and distal humeral shaft. What is the most likely pathogen responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Salmonella is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease. 
  • Sickle cell disease refers to any combination of Hb that includes HbS, whereas sickle cell anemia classically refers to homozygous HbS, and sickle cell trait refers to heterozygous HbS. 
  • Patients with sickle cell anemia often suffer from aplastic crisis, splenic sequestration crisis, acute chest syndrome, and osteomyelitis. Aplastic anemia often arises from infection with parvovirus B19 (fifth disease). 
  • Other common pathogens which cause osteomyelitis in sickle cell patients include Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman returns from a week swimming at the beach and presents to her physician with a complaint of pain in her right ear. Physical examination reveals an area of redness extending from her right ear toward her right mandible that is warm to the touch. The patient's oropharynx is without exudates or erythema. Culture shown in the image. Choose the correct pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • External ear infections caused by P. aeruginosa have two dramatically different presentations: swimmer's ear and malignant otitis externa. 
  • Swimmer's ear occurs in a moist setting (e.g., associated with swimming or a humid environment) and is characterized by an itchy or painful ear with discharge. This is generally treated with agents to dry the ear and antibiotic-containing otic solutions. 
  • Malignant otitis externa is a much more serious progression of swimmer’s ear, with extension and destruction of the underlying bony structures. 
  • This is a condition seen most commonly in the elderly with diabetes.

questions.text: A pathogen isolated from a case of epiglottitis exhibits the property shown in the image. Choose the correct growth factor associated with the bacteria exhibits this property.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • V factor is produced by staphylococci by the lysis of RBCs; hence growth on blood agar can be promoted by providing S. aureus as source of V factor. 
  • Blood agar with S. aureus streak is routinely used for culture and identification of H. influenzae. 
  • In this procedure, a suspected isolate of H. influenzae is streaked on a blood agar plate. Then S. aureus is streaked across the same blood agar plate and incubated at 37°C for 18–24 hours. 
  • After incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae nearer to the S. aureus are larger than those away from it. 
  • This phenomenon is known as satellitism seen in H. influenzae

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was bitten by a cat. Ten hours later the bite wound is purulent and inflamed and rapidly progressive cellulitis seen. The purulent exudate is cultured and reveals gram-negative coccobacilli. Which of the following microorganisms is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • The patient was bitten by a cat carrying Pasteurella multocida, a gram-negative coccobacillus (although there is some variation in morphology) that is part of the normal oral flora in cats and dogs. 
  • It is an aggressive and rapidly spreading infection that can cause skin abscesses, as noted in this patient. 
  • Despite the fact that this is a gram-negative organism, beta lactam antibiotics, such amoxicillin-clavulanate, are highly effective at treating this infect ion and this treatment should be started immediately.

questions.text: Human lymphocytic ehrlichiosis is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Anaplasma phagocytophilum – Human granulocytic ehrlichiosis
  • Ehrlichia sennetsu ( New name – Neorickettsia sennetsu)   - Human lymphocytic ehrlichiosis
  • Ehrlichia chaffeensis – Human monocytic ehrlichiosis

choices.text: Charcoal yeast extract agar with cysteine and iron
Yolk sac of a chick embryo

questions.text: A sample is taken of an ulcer in the inguinal region of a 29-year-old male who has had unprotected sex in the past few months. Intracytoplasmic inclusions are seen in the Giemsa staining Obligate intracellular parasite..  Choose the correct culture for this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Chlamydia is a common sexually transmitted disease.
  •  It is caused by bacteria called Chlamydia trachomatis. It can infect both men and women. 
  • Women can get chlamydia in the cervix, rectum, or throat. Men can get chlamydia in the urethra (inside the penis), rectum, or throat.
  • It is an obligate intracellular
  • It grown in Maccoy cell lines and Chick embryo yolk sac

questions.text: Most sensitive test used in the diagnosis of H. pylori is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Most sensitive, accurate, quick and simple
  • Used for prognosis - monitoring of treatment (becomes negative after improvement) 
  • Culture is most specific but may be insensitive because of difficulty with H. pylori isolation

questions.text: Choose the special laboratory condition needed to recover the pathogen associated with GBS which is gull wing in appearance and exhibits darting motility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Campylobacter species are small motile, non spore forming, comma -shaped, gram-negative bacilli, best grown in a microaerophilic environment at 42 ˚C (107.6 ˚F) on skirrow's selective medium.
  • It exhibits darting motility
  • The complication is GBS

choices.text: The disease is characterized by a rash.
The Weil-Felix test can aid in diagnosis of the disease.
The disease is caused by a Rickettsia
The causative organism is transmitted from rodents to humans by a tick.

questions.text: Each of the following statements concerning epidemic typhus is correct except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Epidemic typhus caused by R. prowazekii transmitted via Louse
  • All other statements are correct

questions.text: A teenager came with the complains of aching muscles and joints and mild fever. He notices a rash on the side of his upper leg as shown in the image. What is the most likely etiology and route of transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Borrelia burgdorferi/tick bite. 
  • The  “bull’s-eye” appearance of the skin lesion, the fever, muscle and joint pain  support a clinical diagnosis of tickborne Lyme disease caused by B. burgdorferi

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of fever and severe pain in her fingers and toes. Treatment with morphine is begun and the girl's symptoms are partially relieved. Physical examination shows a raised facial rash as shown in the image. A peripheral blood smear shows severe anemia, and a bone-marrow aspirate shows no erythroid precursor cells. Infection with which of the following is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Parvoviruses are small single-stranded naked DNA viruses, of which only serotype B19 is pathogenic for humans.
  • This virus causes five distinct syndromes: a childhood febrile "slapped cheek " rash known as erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease), transient aplastic crisis in individuals with chronic hemolytic diseases (sickle-cell anemia, thalassemia, etc.) arthropathy, pure red blood cell aplasia in immunocompromised individuals and congenital infections that can present as stillbirth, hydrops fetalis (analogous to severe Rh incompatibility), or severe anemia 
  • This child has erythema infectiosum or fifth disease. This condition generally begins with fever, coryza, headache, nausea, and diarrhea. Two to five days later, the classic erythematous malar rash appears on the face with relative circumoral pallor ("slapped cheek" rash}. This facial rash is generally followed several days later by a reticulated rash on the trunk and extremities. Hematologic abnormalities, including transient aplastic cell crisis, reticulocytopenia, and reduced hemoglobin concentration. 
  • The transient aplastic crisis (TAC) is characterized by a temporary suspension of erythropoiesis leading to severe anemia and related complications TAC is most common in patients with a history of sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis and iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: A novel infectious disease has become prevalent and increasingly widespread over the past 2 years. The WHO laboratory has just isolated the cause of the illness which is a virus. The virus looks like a brick-shaped complex. It consists of double-stranded enveloped DNA. which replicates in the cytoplasm via a virion-associated transcriptase This new virus would be most likely classified in which of the following families?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Brick shaped DNA virus is Poxviridiae.
  • Examples of viruses in the Poxvirus family are variola, vaccinia, and molluscum contagiosum. All DNAviruses are icosahedral, except for Poxviruses, which are described as brick-shaped complexes. 
  • Poxvirus DNA is enveloped. 
  • All DNA viruses replicate their DNA in the nucleus, except for Poxviruses which replicates in the cytoplasm via virion-associatedtranscriptase.
  • All the enzymes and factors necessary for viral replication are then made in the cytoplasm.

questions.text: The NCDC, India alerted to a recent infectious outbreak in a small  community in South Tamil Nadu. The report states that thirteen cases of hepatitis were confirmed within this community. Of the thirteen cases, the mortality rate is particularly high among pregnant woman. The women initially reported experiencing a varying degree of symptoms including jaundice malaise , anorexia, nausea vomiting, abdominal pain and fever. The most likely causal organism belongs to which of the following viral families?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Hepatitis E  caused by a naked capsid RNA virus belonging to the Hepeviridae (formerly Calciiviridae}. The hepatitis E virus ( HEV ) is an icosahedral nonenveloped single stranded RNA virus Hepatitis E is an important cause of epidemics of enterically transmitted acute hepatitis.
  • In most patients, the hepatitis E virus (HEV) causes a self-limited acute infection; however, fulminant hepatitis may develop.
  • Unlike hepatitis C, chronic hepatitis does not develop after an acute HEV infection. 
  • HEV is spread primarily by fiscally contaminated water in endemic areas. HEV can be transmitted by blood transfusion; however, person-to-person transmission is uncommon.
  • These infections are most common in India, Asia. Africa, and Central America and are associated with a very high mortality among third trimester pregnant women due to fulminant hepatitis.
  • The exact reason for the higher occurrence of pregnant women developing fulminant hepatic failure is not completely understood. However, the relatively immunocompromised state during the third trimester of pregnancy likely plays a role in the inordinately high mortality rate, which approaches 25%
  • The incubation period of HEV infection ranges from 15 to 60 days. Patients with this condition generally experience symptoms similar to other forms of acute viral hepatitis, including jaundice, malaise, vomiting, abdominal pain, fever, and hepatomegaly. 
  • However, some patients have asymptomatic infection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old PLHIV man presents to the ophthalmologist complaining of worsening vision for the past two weeks and seeing new flashes and floaters in his right eye. He reports no pain in his right eye nor is there any redness. On ophthalmoscopic examination finding shown in the image. Choose the best test to diagnose this disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • This PLHIV male is experiencing CMV retinitis caused by the cytomegalovirus (CMV) which is a linear, dsDNA enveloped virus. 
  • CMV, or human herpes virus type 5, is a linear, dsDNA, enveloped virus that is transmitted via the following routes: congenital, blood transfusion, sex, saliva, urine, and transplantation. Once CMV has established its initial infection, it establishes a latent infection within mononuclear cells. CMV causes mononucleosis in immunocompentent individuals. In infants.
  • It causes cytomegalic inclusion disease resulting in neonatal jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytic purpura, hearing loss, and seizures. In the immunocompromised (e.g. individuals with AIDS or transplant patients taking immunosuppressive medications), it causes retinitis and pneumonia. 
  • Lab diagnosis : 1. PP65 antigen detection, RTPCR. Biopsy shows owl eye appearance.

choices.text: Posterior horn cells of the spinal cord
Anterior horn cells of spinal cord

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy recently immigrated from Pakistan presents with fever, muscle pain, and weakness of the trunk. abdomen. and legs. The patient's mother says that he has not been vaccinated. Physical exam reveals fasciculation and ﬂaccid paralysis of the lower limbs. A CSF analysis reveals lymphocytosis with normal glucose and protein levels. Throat swab reveals an RNA virus. Which of the following would most likely be destroyed by the virus in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • The patient most likely has acute poliomyelitis. caused by the poliovirus, a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Enterovirus family. Poliovirus destroys the motor neurons of the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, resulting in ﬂaccid asymmetric paralysis and muscle atrophy. The disease has 2 basic patterns: 

1. Abortive poliomyelitis: a minor self-limited illness which does not involve , the central nervous system (CNS). 
2. Acute flaccid paralysis: a major paralytic illness which involves the CNS.. 

  • About 1-5 in 1,000 cases progresses to paralytic disease in which skeletal muscles become poorly controlled, weak, ﬂoppy, and atrophied. Poliovirus is a highly contagious. It spreads by the fecal-oral route and by respiratory  droplets. Several factors that increase the risk of polio infection and affect the severity of the disease include comorbid immune deﬁciency, malnutrition, and so engaging in physical activity immediately following the onset of paralysis. The poliovirus vaccine is very successful and almost all countries, except Pakistan and Afghanistan, have been largely polio-free due to proper immunization.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman in her second trimester of pregnancy develops arthritic symptoms and a maculopapular rash in her trunk. Serologic tests are negative for IgM antibodies to parvovirus B 19 and measles virus, but the tests are positive for IgM antibodies to rubella virus and for IgG antibodies to measles and rubella viruses. The infant is at highest risk for having which condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • A maculopapular rash can be caused by parvovirus B19. measles, or rubella virus. Rubella is indicated by the presence of virus-specific IgM and IgG in an unvaccinated individual. 
  • Deafness is associated with rubella virus infection in any trimester. 
  • The earlier the infection, the more severe is the outcome and the higher is the infant's risk for mental retardation, cardiac problems, and cataracts. 
  • Cerebral calcification is associated with congenital CMV infection. 
  • Chorioretinitis is the most common congenital defect associated with Toxoplasma infection. 
  • Hydrops fetalis is associated with parvovirus B19 infection. 
  • Keratoconjunctivitis is a manifestation of HSV infection in adults

choices.text: He has recovered from HBV infection and is immune to HBV.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man with a history of IV drug use was found to have abnormal liver function tests.  Further work-up including serologic tests for viral hepatitis show 
Hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) negative 
Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) positive 
Hepatitis core antibodyIgG (HBcAb) positive 
Hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) negative 
Hepatitis B e antibody (HBeAb) positive 
Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) negative 
Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • In the interpretation of results of hepatitis B serologic tests, the following facts should be considered: during the incubation period (i.e., before the onset of clinical manifestations) HbsAg, HbeAg, and HBV DNA become detectable in the serum. 
  • At the onset of clinical symptoms (e.g., jaundice), an increase in the serum transaminases antibodies occurs and antibodies to HBc become detectable (HBc antibodies). 
  • Initially, the HBc antibodies are IgM and thereafter IgG; these latter antibodies persist for years. 
  • HBs antibodies become detectable late in convalescence. 
  • A rise in HBs antibodies in combination with a loss of HbsAg, HbeAg, and HBV DNA indicate the presence of immunity to HBV. 
  • HbeAg and HBV DNA are markers of active viral replication and thus indicate high infectivity. 
  • The loss of HbeAg and appearance of anti-HbeAb indicates a less infective stage.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought with severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting with blood, restlessness, and a bloody nose. Patient history is signiﬁcant for 5 days of high fever with headache, joint pain, rash, and retroorbital eye pain.  Laboratory values demonstrate a 20% rise in hematocrit levels, elevated AST levels, severe thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and a positive tourniquet test. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic agent causing this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • This patient is infected with dengue virus and is transitioning from DHF to dengue shock syndrome (DSS). 
  • Not all patients that have dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) will progress to DSS, but advanced warning signs include severe abdominal pain, protracted vomiting, marked change in temperature, and/or change in mental status. 
  • Early signs of DSS include restlessness, cold clammy skin, rapid weak pulse, and/or hypotension. 
  • The tourniquet test can be used to screen for dengue virus infections and is an indication of capillary fragility and thrombocyotopenia. For this test a patient’s blood pressure is measured and recorded. The blood pressure cuﬀ is then inﬂated to half way between the systole and diastolic pressure for 5 minutes. A positive test is one in which there are more than 10 petechiae/square inch.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man who has sex with men presents with a mass on his perianal region as shown in the image. He states the mass is itchy, tender, and burns but does not hurt. His vials are unremarkable. Physical examination of the anus reveals the ﬁndings seen in the following image. The rest of his physical exam is unremarkable. The TPPA test is negative. Choose the serotype responsible for this.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Genital warts -Condyloma acuminata – HPV 6,11
  • Human cervical cancer – 16,18,31,33
  • Common warts – 1,2,3,4
  • HHV 8 – Kaposi sarcoma

questions.text: Name the vaccine strain used to prevent the pathognomonic lesions of a viral disease shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Image shown here is Koplik spots – pathognomic for Measles.
  • Vaccine strain – Edmonston Zagreb strain.
  • OKA – VZV
  • Jeryl – Lynn – Mumps
  • 17D – Yellow fever

questions.text: A 25-year-old intern who is seronegative for VZV is exposed to a patient with chickenpox. Which treatment would be the most appropriate to prevent VZV disease in the intern?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Varicella-zoster immune globulin (VZIG) is used to prevent infection in exposed susceptible individuals.
  • Routine prevention in immunocompetent individuals – VZV vaccine.
  • Seronegative, exposed, immunocompetent – Vaccine + VZIg
  • Seronegative exposed, Immunocompromised – VZIg only
  • Risk of exposure – Only VZV vaccine.

questions.text: An epidemic of nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea breaks out on shipboard during a cruise to the Andaman Islands. Which of the following accurately describes the most likely causal agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • A common cause of gastroenteritis on cruise ships is the Norovirus. 
  • Norovirus is a member of the Caliciviridae family and is a nonenveloped RNA virus. 
  • Acid-fast oocysts refer to persistent diarrhea caused by Cryptosporidium parvum or Isospora belli, usually seen in AIDS patients. 
  • Enveloped DNA and RNA viruses cannot be transmitted via the fecal-oral route or live in the gastrointestinal tract because of the instability of the envelope.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is bitten on the face by a rabid dog. The disease progresses in an uncharacteristically rapid manner, and the patient dies. Choose the correct strategy to manage this condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Bite on the face – Category III bite
  • Wound toileting – Category I
  • Rabies Vaccine + Wound toileting – Category II
  • Rabies Vaccine + Rig +  Wound toileting – category III

questions.text: A 9-month-old child is hospitalized with viral pneumonia. Which virus is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • All the viruses listed can cause pneumonia; however, by far, the most common cause of pneumonia in childrenless than 1 year of age is respiratory syncytial virus 
  • It belongs to Paramyxoviridiae

questions.text: A COVID19 vaccine image is given here. This vaccine belongs to which type?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Covaxin – Killed vaccine
  • Covishield – Adenovirus vector recombinant vaccine
  • Moderna – mRNA vaccine
  • Novavax – Subunit vaccine
  • No Live attenuated vaccine currently available for COVID19

questions.text: Choose the correct virus based on the ecology shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • This graphic shows the ecological cycle for the Kyasanur Forest Disease virus. 
  • The hard tick Haemaphysalis spinagera is both the reservoir and the vector for the virus. 
  • Transmission to humans can occur directly through contact with ticks, or through contact with infected monkeys and small animals. 
  • Larger animals may become infected, but play a limited role in transmission of disease to humans. 
  • No human-to-human transmission has been documented.

choices.text: Culture of organism on MacConkey agar
Demonstration of IgM antibodies against the agent

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to his family physician in a small town with an acute onset of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Hepatomegaly and icteric sclera are noted on physical exam. Alanine transferase and aspartate transferase levels are markedly elevated. Over the next 3 days, 10 more people in the same town seek medical attention with similar complaints. How is the most likely cause of this outbreak definitively diagnosed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • The case describes an outbreak of an infectious cause of acute hepatitis. 
  • The most common infectious cause of acute hepatitis is hepatitis A virus. 
  • This agent is diagnosed by the demonstration of IgM antiviral antibodies in the patient’s serum.
  • Although virus is shed in the stool, most viral shedding occurs prior to the onset of symptoms. 
  • Thus, demonstration of virus in stool is not a method of diagnosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, sore throat, nasal congestion, and violent coughing. The physician notes that the child has a loud, "barking" cough. On auscultation, there is an inspiratory stridor. Between coughing spells, the child is noted to have intercostal retractions. What is the RNA genome structure of the most common virus causing this child's illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • This child's symptoms, especially the "barking " cough and the finding of inspiratory stridor, are consistent with a diagnosis of croup, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus of the Paramyxoviridae family. 
  • Paramyxoviruses have an envelope and a helical capsid . 
  • They are single-stranded, negative-sense, linear,  nonsegmented RNA viruses. 
  • Other illnesses caused by paramyxoviruses include respiratory syncytial virus, measles, and mumps.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male presents to the emergency department for fatigue and lethargy. Upon presentation, the patient is found to be severely dehydrated. The patient's mother says that he has been having non-bloody diarrhea for a day. She also says that the patient has not received any vaccinations after 6 months and currently attends a daycare center. The responsible microbe is isolated, and its structure is analyzed. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the symptoms seen in this child.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • The young child in this question presents with non-bloody diarrhea most likely caused by infection with rotavirus. 
  • Rotavirus is the leading cause of fatal diarrhea in children and is very contagious. It can therefore cause outbreaks of diarrhea in settings where many children are gathered such as in daycare centers. 
  • Alternative diagnoses for watery diarrhea include E. coli, which causes diarrhea in travelers, and norovirus, which is more common in adults and can cause outbreaks in confined spaces such as cruise ships.

choices.text: Zika virus vector is ixodid tick
Hantavirus spread by inhalation of rodent urine and feces
KFD is caused by bite of wild animal
Lyssa virus is transmitted by tick

questions.text: Choose the correct statement
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Hantaviruses are natural pathogens of rodents, viremia is present in infected rodents and virus is shed in urine, feces and saliva in high titres.
  • Transmission from rodent to humans is primarily respiratory; by inhalation of the virus contained in the dried excreta.
  • Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) is transmitted by bite of infected ticks
  • Lyssa virus (Rabies virus) transmitted by bite of infected rabid dogs/ mammals.

questions.text: Inclusion body produced by the agent causing this clinical condition is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • It’s a case of small pox eradicated from the universe.
  • Small pox – Paschen bodies
  • Vaccinia – Guarneri bodies
  • Rabies – Negri bodies
  • Molluscum – Henderson Peterson bodies
  • Fowl pox – Bollinger bodies

questions.text: Seronegative infectious mononucleosis is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Seronegative glandular fever or infectious mononucleosis is caused by CMV.
  • Mimics like infectious mononucleosis but Monospot / Paul Bunnel tests are negative.

questions.text: An 12-year-old boy is taken to his pediatrician because his mother noticed a raised, scaly area on the back of his head. The physician notes that the area is approximately 5 cm in diameter with an inflamed, raised border. He collects scrapings of the area, and a mold grows on SDA. LPCB wet mount shown in the image. Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient's infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Trichophyton: infects skin, hair, and nails
  • Only macroconidia are present in the Epidermophyton infection. 
  • Few macroconidia and more microconidia are present in Trichophyton infection. 
  • Macroconidia are predominantly present in Microsporum infection.

questions.text: A severely neutropenic, immunocompromised patient presents with hemoptysis and pneumonia. Culture of Bronchial alveolar fluid on SDA shown in the image. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Severe neutropenia and the colony morphology suggestive of Aspergillus infection.
  • In culture on SDA agar different Aspergillus species produce colonies of various colors. 
  • A. fumigatus produces tan green y colony
  •  A. niger – Black colour colony
  • A. flavus  - Yellowish green colony
  • The isolation of Aspergillus by culture needs to be interpreted with care because they are common laboratory contaminants. Repeated isolation of the fungi may be of helpful to suggest the pathogenic role of the Aspergillus.

choices.text: Long, branching hyphae with acute angles

questions.text: A 30 year old florist presents with a subcutaneous lesions on the hand as shown in the image, which she thinks resulted from a thorn prick. What would be the expected structure seen in the biopsy specimen to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • It’s a case of Sporotrichosis
  • S. schenckii occurs in two phases. 
  • Yeast phase occurs in  tissue and in culture at 37°C, while mycelium phase occurs in  culture 
  • at 22–25°C. 
  • In infected tissue, the yeast appears as round, oval, or cigarshaped cells with irregular borders. 
  • Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) or Gomori’s methenamine silver (GMS) stain is useful to demonstrate these structures in the stained smears. 
  • The fungus on SDA at 25°C produces black and shiny colonies, which become wrinkled and foggy during course of time. 
  • The mold contains hyphae bearing flower-like structures of small conidia on delicate sterigmata.

choices.text: Tinea corporis, Tinea unguium, and Tinea versicolor

questions.text: Fungal cells that reproduce by budding are seen in the infected tissues of patients with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Among the options, only these three fungus available in Yeast form with budding daughter cells.
  • Mucormycosis – Aseptate hyphae
  • Tinea – Micro and Macro conidia
  • Aspergillosis – septate hyphae

questions.text: A 32-year-old man admitted with chronic pneumonia malaise, weight loss, night sweats, chest pain, breathlessness, and hoarseness. Sputum GMS smear shown in the image. What is the most common site of dissemination for the causal organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • The image shown here and the history suggestive of Blastomyces infection.
  • Dimorphic fungus
  • B. dermatitidis infection occurs by inhalation of microconidia found in soil, its natural habitat. Inside the lungs, the conidia  are transformed to the yeast phase at body temperature. 
  • Pulmonary infection is the major clinical manifestation. 
  • In some cases, it may develop to a progressive pulmonary disease or may result in extrapulmonary dissemination. 
  • Extrapulmonary dissemination to other organs, more often, occurs in patients with chronic pulmonary illness and in those who are immunocompromised. 
  • The skin is the most common site of extrapulmonary blastomycosis.

questions.text: A COVID19 recovered patient with uncontrolled diabetes suffers from a soft tissue infection and microbiological examination revealed the pathogen as shown in the image. Name the fungal disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Image shown here depicts aseptate hyphae with right angel branching suggestive of Mucormycosis.
  • The major predisposing factor is Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).
  • Angio invasive in nature

choices.text: Molds produce hyphae that may or may not be partitioned with cross-walls or septa.
Conidia are produced only by sexual reproduction
Most pathogenic dimorphic molds produce hyphae in the host and yeasts at 25°C.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Molds produce either septate or aseptate hyphae.
  • Conidia are asexual spores
  • Dimorphic fungi are molds at 25°C and yeasts at 370C

questions.text: A severely immunosuppressed man admitted with severe head ache and few episodes of unusual behavior. On physical examination, cutaneous lesions on his arms, torso, and legs are noted. A spinal tap is ordered. CSF Gram stain shown in the image. What is the selective medium used to confirm this pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • The picture and the clinical features suggestive of Cryptococcal meningitis.
  • The selective medium for demonstration of melanin pigment is Bird seed agar or Niger seed agar or Staib agar.
  • It produces black to brown colonies.

questions.text: A 27-year-old PLHIV admitted with progressively increasing dyspnea over the past 3 weeks. He also complains of a dry, painful cough, fatigue, and low-grade fever. A chest x-ray reveals bilateral symmetrical interstitial and alveolar infiltration. Which of the following agents is the most likely cause of the above?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • The clues are AIDS patient and atypical pneumonia. Pneumocystis jirovecii is the hallmark atypical pneumonia of AIDS.
  • Pneumocystis is classified under fungus based on nucleic acid sequence studies:
  • It exist in two forms - In environment cysts are found, whereas in human tissues both cysts and trophozoites are found.
  • Cysts are inhaled, carried to the lungs, transformed into trophozoite stage which induces an inflammatory response that leads to recruitment of plasma cells resulting in formation of frothy exudate filling the alveoli – Honey comb appearance.

questions.text: Parasite happens to reach a place where it cannot live is defined as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Temporary Parasite: Visits its host for a short period. 
  • Permanent Parasite: Leads a parasitic life throughout the whole period of its life. 
  • Facultative Parasite: Lives a parasitic life when opportunity arises. 
  • Obligatory Parasite: Cannot exist without a parasitic life.
  • Occasional or Accidental Parasite'. Attacks an unusual host.
  • Wandering or Aberrant Parasite: Happens to reach a place where it cannot live.

questions.text: A 23 year old man was admitted with liver abscess, The pus aspirate shown in the image. In microscopic examination of the pus, what would be the diagnostic form for this clinical condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • It’s a case of Amoebic liver abscess.
  • Anchovy sauce pus
  • Diagnostic stage is motile trophozoite.

questions.text: 22 year old swimmer presented with features of acute meningoencephalitis in the casualty. His CSF on wet mount microscopy shown in the picture revealed the pathogen. What is the infective form of this pathogen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Image shown here is trophozoite stage of Naegleria fowleri.
  • It causes primary amoebic meningoencephalitis.
  • The drug of choice is amphotericin-B intravenously. It can also be instilled directly into the brain.

questions.text: An HIV-infected patient develops profuse, watery diarrhea. His physician collects stool specimens for bacterial, fungal, mycobacterial, and parasitology examination. Later that day, the clinical laboratory telephones the physician and informs her that acid-fast oocysts are observed on parasitology examination as shown in the image. Which organism most likely responsible for these infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • The infective form of the parasite is oocyst.
  • The oocyst is oval and measures about 15 – 35 µm in diameter.
  • Cystisospora belli.
  • Oocysts stain with acid fast staining.

questions.text: A 26 year women came for gynaecological examination was found to have Colpitis macularis as shown in the image. What is etiological agent responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Image shown here is Strawberry cervix caused by T. vaginalis
  • 2% of women with the infection will have a "strawberry" cervix (colpitis macularis, an erythematous cervix with pinpoint areas of exudation) or vagina on examination.
  • This is due to capillary dilation as a result of the inflammatory response.

choices.text: To treat the exoerythrocytic stages and reduce the chance of relapse
To prevent the emergence of resistant strains of this organism
To treat coinfection with a related organism
To prevent central nervous system manifestations

questions.text: A 40-year man, seeks medical care because of an incapacitating febrile illness of 4 days duration. On examination, the patient has a temperature of 104 °F and complains of generalized body aches and pains. Laboratory blood work reveals pancytopenia and decreased hemoglobin. A blood smear is shown in the image. Chloroquine was prescribed and, within days, the patient made a dramatic recovery. The infectious disease resident caring for the patient is recommended a combination therapy that included primaquine. Choose the appropriate justification for this prescription to the resident.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Chloroquine by itself is considered incomplete therapy. 
  • Plasmodium vivax, due to the hypnozoite stage in the liver, will relapse every few months for 3 to 5 years. 
  • Primaquine targets this stage of the parasite. 
  • Although P. vivax, if left untreated, can lead to organ damage, cerebral malaria, and renal manifestations (blackwater fever) are typically associated with P. falciparum.

questions.text: A 48-year-old NRI man was admitted to the hospital after complaining of fever and shortness of breath. Radiographs revealed an enlarged heart and complete blood count smear results revealed rare C-shaped trypomastigote forms. The patient was an active military duty years ago in the Panama Canal zone. The most likely parasite is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • A case of T.cruzi infection
  • 'Chagoma' is the typical subcutaneous lesion occurring at the site of inoculation. 
  • Mega cardia, mega colon and mega ureter are the features.
  • Inoculation of the parasite in conjunctiva causes unilateral, painless edema of perioccular tissues in the eye called as Romana’s sign.
  • This is a classical finding of the acute Chagas' disease.
  • In few patients, there may be generalized infection with fever, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly.
  • The patient may die of acute myocarditis and meningoencephalitis.

questions.text: In Balantidium coli life cycle, Human acts as a
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • B. coli passes its life cycle in one host only (monoxenous). 
  • Natural host: Pig. 
  • Accidental host: Man.

questions.text: A 52-year old man from removed an insect attached to his forearm after returning from a weekend camping trip. Image shown here revealed the insect. It act as a vector for which one of the following pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Leishmania – Sandfly
  • T. cruzi – Reduviid bug
  • O. volvulus – Simulium fly

questions.text: All the following Parasites are causing  Transfusion Transmitted infections (TTI) except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • The Parasitic causes of TTI are
  • Plasmodium
  • Leishmania
  • Trypanosoma
  • Toxoplasma
  • Babesia

questions.text: Choose the correct pathogen causing Chiclero's ulcer
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Leishmania mexicana  complex – Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis (Chiclero’s ulcer)
  • Vecoor - Lutzomyra species
  • Reservoir : Forest rodents and marsupials
  • L. brasiliensis – Espundia
  • L.tropica – Oriental sore.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with a prolapsed rectum. Examination of the rectum reveals small worms attached to the mucosa as shown in the image. A stool sample reveals eggs that are barrel shaped, with bipolar plugs. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Barrel shaped egg with bipolar plugs – Trichuris trichiura
  • Heavy worm load of T. trichiura in children leads to rectal prolapse. 
  • It looks like coconut cake rectum. 
  • In adults it causes iron deficiency anaemia.

questions.text: Second intermediate host for Paragonimus westermani is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Crab is the 2nd Intermediate host for P. westermani
  • Aquatic plant is the 2nd Intermediate host for F. hepatica and F. buski
  • Fish is the 2nd Intermediate host for C. sinensis

questions.text: Choose the correct cestode that doesn’t need an intermediate host to complete the life cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • H. nana – No intermediate host
  • T saginata – Cattle
  • T. solium - Pork
  • E. granulosus – Human
  • D. latum – Cyclops and Fish

questions.text: A 16 year old boy came to OPD with painless terminal hematuria. Urine microscopy revealed the pathogen as shown in the image. Choose the correct infective stage of the pathogen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Image shown here is egg of Schistosoma hematobium.
  • The infective stage of S. hematobium is cercariae and mode of transmission is skin penetration.
  • Other trematodes, infective stage is metacercariae.

questions.text: Name the arrow marked structure in the lifecycle of an blood fluke
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Image shown here is lifecycle of Schistosoma mansoni. (clue – Eggs with lateral spine)
  • Egg hatch in the fresh water and become larval stage called Miracidium.
  • Miracidium enter into the intermediate host – fresh water snails.

questions.text: A 28 year old man presents with an enlarged scrotum. The man reports that his scrotum is gradually “getting bigger.” During the medical history, he also expresses alarm that his urine appears milky—giving the physician theimpression that he is also suffering from chylous urine. Peripheral blood microscopy shown in the image. with which organism is he most likely infected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Hydrocoele is a very common manifestation of filariasis. Accumulation of fluid occurs due to obstruction of lymph vessels of the spermatic cord and also by exudation from the inflamed testes and epididymis. 
  • The fluid is usually clear and straw coloured, but may sometimes be cloudy, milky,  orhemorrhagic.
  • Rupture of lymph varices leading to release of lymph or chyle and resulting in chyluria, chylous diarrhea, chylous ascites, and chycothorax, depending on the involved site.

questions.text: A 9-yearold girl who appears with thin & “potbelly” of malnutrition. The paediatrician orders a fecal exam and CBC. The CBC reveals a microcytic, hypochromic anemia, and the fecal exam detects brown, oval nematode eggs as shown in the image. What was the most likely means by which this child was infected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • The microscopy reveals Hook worm egg.
  • Oval or elliptical, measuring 60 µm by 40 µm.
  • Colorless, not bile stained.
  • Surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane.
  • Floats in saturated salt solution.
  • When released by the worm in the intestine, the egg contains an unsegmented ovum.
  • During its passage down the intestine, the ovum develops. When passed in feces, the egg contains a segmented ovum, usually with 4 or 8 blastomeres.
  • There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and the egg shell.
  • Mode of transmission is skin penetration by filariform larvae.

questions.text: Autoinfection is seen in all the following helminths except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Autoinfection causing parasites
  • Cryptosporidium
  • H. nana
  • vermicularis
  • S. stercoralis

T. solium

questions.text: Smallest nematode causing human infection is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • It is the smallest nematode causing hyperinfection syndrome in immunocompromised.
  • Smallest cestode is H. nana – dwarf tape worm
